importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The federal government shutdown was ongoing as of this date, affecting financial systems and daily operations across the U.S.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The shutdown is currently active, with ongoing financial and employment consequences for individuals and businesses.

keyTakeAways: Federal workers are being laid off in thousands, disrupting public services.
Local businesses—both in Washington, DC, and outside national parks—are struggling to hire staff.
Federally-backed housing loans are halted, preventing people from moving into new homes.
The shutdown has significant financial implications for individuals (lack of income) and businesses (inability to operate).

namedEntities.name: federal government
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: a government body in the United States responsible for implementing public policies and services
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The federal government shutdown is the central event driving financial and operational disruptions described in the article.

namedEntities.name: Ramishah Maruf
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the author of the article and provides a journalistic perspective on the financial impacts of the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The article is published by CNN, indicating it is a credible source of public information on governmental events.

namedEntities.name: Washington, DC
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: a major U.S. city and capital of the United States
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is cited as a location where local businesses are affected by the shutdown, showing regional economic impact.

namedEntities.name: national parks
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: protected natural areas managed by the federal government
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Outside national parks, businesses are affected, indicating broader geographic reach of the shutdown's economic toll.

namedEntities.name: local businesses
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: small or regional enterprises operating in communities
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: These businesses are struggling to hire employees, showing the economic ripple effects of government inaction.

namedEntities.name: federally-backed housing loans
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: loans guaranteed or supported by federal agencies
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The halt in these loans prevents people from moving into new homes, directly affecting personal financial planning.

namedEntities.name: individuals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The article directly addresses how personal finances are affected by the lack of federal employment and services.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The federal government shutdown has severely disrupted daily life and finances for many Americans. Thousands of federal workers have been laid off, local businesses across the nation—including in Washington, DC and outside national parks—are struggling to hire staff, and federally-backed housing loans have been halted, preventing people from moving into new homes. This has significant financial consequences for individuals facing job loss and for businesses unable to maintain operations, highlighting the broad economic ripple effects of government inaction.
title: How has the federal government shutdown affected your wallet?
